triples.name: Blockchain
triples.relevance: Blockchains are the underlying trusted layer that arbitration games aim to scale through layer two solutions.

triples.name: Lean (proof assistant)
triples.relevance: Lean is the formal verification tool used to mechanize the arbitration games and machine-check the strategies.

triples.name: Hash function
triples.relevance: Hash functions are used as compact witnesses in arbitration games to represent knowledge without revealing computation details.

triples.name: Merkle tree
triples.relevance: Merkle trees provide the hierarchical structure for encoding data availability and membership proofs in arbitration games.

triples.name: Formal verification
triples.relevance: Formal verification is the core methodology for machine-checking that proposed strategies guarantee honest player success.

triples.name: Rollup
triples.relevance: Layer two rollups, specifically optimistic rollups, are the blockchain scaling architecture that depends on arbitration games.

triples.name: Binary tree
triples.relevance: Binary trees are the underlying structure on which arbitration games operate, particularly for data-availability assertions.

triples.name: Game theory
triples.relevance: Game theory provides the foundational framework for understanding arbitration games as strategic interactions between two opposing players.

triples.name: Proof assistant
triples.relevance: Proof assistants enable interactive theorem proving for mechanizing the winning strategies and their correctness guarantees.

triples.name: Arbitration game
triples.relevance: The paper proposes the first formal abstractions and machine-checkable strategies for arbitration games in Lean.
